gravity_system: Floating Slab, Load Bearing Edge, Non-Load Bearing Edge
other_materials: Extruded Polystyrene, Compacted Granular 'A', Welded Wire Mesh
key_elements: Floating Slab, Load Bearing Edge, Non-Load Bearing Edge, Intermediate Thickening
overall_building_description: The foundation system for the Wayne Mckeown project at 182 Barton Street, Hamilton, ON, is characterized by a floating slab design, which is a common choice for residential structures due to its cost-effectiveness and ease of construction. The slab dimensions are precisely 24 feet by 35 feet, providing a stable base for the structure above. The foundation plan, as detailed in the drawings, includes a comprehensive layout of grid lines labeled 1-4 horizontally and A-G vertically, which are crucial for ensuring accurate placement and alignment during construction. The foundation's load-bearing capacity is enhanced by the use of 15M rebar, strategically placed at both the top and bottom of the slab sections, ensuring adequate tensile strength to resist bending moments. The reinforcement layout includes (3) 15M rebar at the top and bottom of load-bearing edges, with additional (2) 15M hooked bars for enhanced anchorage, as specified in the section details. The use of Hilti Kwik Bolt 3 Wedge Anchors, with a minimum embedment of 4 inches, or equivalent anchoring systems, ensures robust connection to the substrate, providing lateral stability and resistance to uplift forces. The foundation's insulation strategy incorporates a minimum of 2 inches (R10) of extruded polystyrene, possessing a compressive strength of 30 psi, which is critical for thermal resistance and moisture protection. This insulation is complemented by a 6 mil poly layer, acting as a vapor barrier to prevent moisture ingress. The base preparation involves compacted granular 'A', a well-graded aggregate that provides a stable and level surface for the slab, enhancing load distribution and minimizing settlement. The sections also detail a 2% slope away from the structure, facilitating effective drainage and reducing hydrostatic pressure against the foundation. The welded wire mesh, specified as 6"x6"-6/6 or a 10M grid at 10 inches on center, provides additional reinforcement, distributing loads evenly across the slab and preventing cracking. The intermediate thickening sections are reinforced with continuous 15M rebar, hooked at the ends to ensure continuity and effective load transfer across the slab. The construction details emphasize the importance of proper cover for the rebar, as noted in the drawings, to prevent corrosion and ensure longevity. The foundation design adheres to relevant building codes and standards, ensuring compliance with structural integrity and safety requirements. The use of specific materials and reinforcement configurations reflects a well-considered approach to foundation design, balancing structural performance with cost-efficiency. The detailed specifications, including material grades and reinforcement layouts, provide a clear roadmap for construction, ensuring that all elements are executed to the highest standards. The drawings also highlight the importance of spatial relationships, with section callouts linking plan and section views, facilitating a comprehensive understanding of the foundation's geometry and load paths. This meticulous attention to detail in the design and documentation process ensures that the foundation will perform effectively under the anticipated loads, providing a reliable base for the residential structure above.
